abstract.text: Photobleaching event counting is a single-molecule fluorescence technique that is increasingly being used to determine the stoichiometry of protein and RNA complexes composed of many subunits in vivo as well as in vitro.
By tagging protein or RNA subunits with fluorophores, activating them, and subsequently observing as the fluorophores photobleach, one obtains information on the number of subunits in a complex.
The noise properties in a photobleaching time trace depend on the number of active fluorescent subunits.

Thus, as fluorophores stochastically photobleach, noise properties of the time trace change stochastically, and these varying noise properties have created a challenge in identifying photobleaching steps in a time trace.
Although photobleaching steps are often detected by eye, this method only works for high individual fluorophore emission signal-to-noise ratios and small numbers of fluorophores.
With filtering methods or currently available algorithms, it is possible to reliably identify photobleaching steps for up to 20-30 fluorophores and signal-tonoise ratios down to ∼1.

Here we present a new Bayesian method of counting steps in photobleaching time traces that takes into account stochastic noise variation in addition to complications such as overlapping photobleaching events that may arise from fluorophore interactions, as well as on-off blinking.

Our method is capable of detecting ≥50 photobleaching steps even for signal-to-noise ratios as low as 0.1, can find up to ≥500 steps for more favorable noise profiles, and is computationally inexpensive.

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION
Fluorophores photobleach when exposed to light over time.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: That is, they irreversibly photochemically transition to a state no longer detectable by fluorescence (White and Stelzer, 1999;Lippincott-Schwartz et al., 2003).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Although photobleaching can be a nuisance in single-particle tracking experiments, it is critical to other experimental approaches, such as fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (Lippincott-Schwartz et al., 2003), photoactivated localization microscopy (PALM), and photobleaching event counting (Lippincott-Schwartz et al., 2003;Leake et al., 2006;Ulbrich and Isacoff, 2007;Coffman and Wu, 2012).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: As its name implies, photobleaching event counting is used to enumerate molecules by monitoring how the light intensity in some region decreases by quanta as individual fluorophores photobleach (Shu et al., 2007).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This can be very useful in quantifying the stoichiometry of biological complexes in live cells (Leake et al., 2006).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Briefly, photobleaching event counting works by tagging biomolecule subunits-often genetically (Durisic et al., 2014)-with fluorophores.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Fluorophores within an illuminated region of interest (ROI) are then all simultaneously activated and monitored as they subsequently photobleach.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: As each fluorophore photobleaches, the fluorescence intensity over a ROI drops in a step-like pattern.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Each step-like Brute-force application of many methods, including our own, that rank-order models by evaluating and comparing model posteriors for all possible models (i.e., all possible numbers of steps with any possible step location) is computationally prohibitive.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Instead, our method is efficient in its implementation because it uses a precursor algorithm to eliminate from consideration a large number of unlikely models.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: It then considers and compares only probable models.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This two-step approach reduces the computational complexity and makes it possible for us to apply our method to photobleaching traces with as many as 100+ fluorophores, depending on the level of noise.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In fact, using our method, we show that even for low SNR, we can count up to 50+ fluorophores and locate photobleaching events in a time trace with an accuracy surpassing that of methods currently available.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: We also show that we can extract biological conclusions by applying our method to sample experimental data sets.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: We previously proposed a solution to the single-molecule counting problem using PALM (Rollins et al., 2015), in which we inferred the (stochastic) blinking properties of fluorophores "on the fly" in order to avoid overcounting fluorophores-and thus protein subunits-in an ROI.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Although PALM provides greater spatial resolution than photobleaching event counting, allowing us to characterize complexes localized down to the tens of nanometers (Watanabe et al., 2011), PALM analysis is computationally intensive.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The advantage of photobleaching, and the reason we focus on this here, is that photobleaching event counting has the potential to reveal the stoichiometry of complexes involving hundreds of proteins.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Unfortunately, current analysis methods have limited its applicability to complexes with only a handful of subunits.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: As we show, complicated fluorophore photophysics can be accommodated in our approach.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Thus our work even suggests that future experiments may want to focus on biological problems, such as characterizing larger protein complexes, rather than engineering photophysical properties of fluorophores used in photobleaching event counting to reduce blinking, which may now be treated theoretically in postprocessing.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

A photobleaching time trace is a data set consisting of fluorescence intensity measurements taken at constant time intervals ∆t and decrease corresponds to a single or possibly multiple overlapping photobleaching events.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: The total number of photobleaching events can then be used, in principle, to determine the total number of fluorophore-tagged molecules present within the ROI (Das et al., 2007).
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: For instance, photobleaching event counting has been used to quantify the stoichiometry of a number of complexes involved in the bacterial flagellar switch (FliM; Delalez et al., 2010), eukaryotic flagella (Engel et al., 2009), and the point centromere (Lawrimore et al., 2011;Coffman et al., 2011).
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: It also has been used to determine the stoichiometry of complexes and biomolecules such as mammalian neurotransmitter receptors (McGuire et al., 2012), human calcium channels (Demuro et al., 2011), transmembrane α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptor-regulatory proteins (Hastie et al., 2013), T4 bacteriophage helicase loader protein (Arumugam et al., 2009), bacterial oxidative phosphorylation complexes (Llorente-Garcia et al., 2014), microRNAs in processing bodies (Pitchiaya et al., 2012(Pitchiaya et al., , 2014, RNAs in a bacteriophage DNA-packaging motor (Shu et al., 2007), and other membrane protein and protein complex stoichiometries (Leake et al., 2006;Das et al., 2007).
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Although counting photobleaching steps is conceptually straightforward, the noise inherent to photobleaching traces makes it difficult to identify the number of steps and their location ( Figure 1).
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: One key challenge is that the magnitude of the noise changes stochastically along with the number of active fluorophores.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Thus a detection algorithm assuming constant noise properties is inappropriate for photobleaching.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: In addition, noise also arises from background fluorescence (Ulbrich and Isacoff, 2007;Coffman and Wu, 2012), variable fluorophore emission (Ulbrich and Isacoff, 2007), and fluorophore blinking (Bagshaw and Cherny, 2006) driven by core fluorophore instabilities (Drobizhev et al., 2012).
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: For this reason, photobleaching event counting is typically used only in systems with few fluorophores (<10), for which signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is high.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Here SNR is defined as μ f /σ f , where μ f and σ f are the mean and SD of the emission intensity of the single fluorophore, respectively.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: For instance, in Ulbrich and Isacoff (2007), five subunits was the limit past which detection of discrete steps, done by eye, became difficult.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Figure 1 shows an example of a photobleaching trace along with its increasing noise level as more fluorophores become active.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Earlier counting methods used filters-such as the median filter or the Chung-Kennedy filter (Leake et al., 2006)-as well as binning and constructing pairwise distance distributions (Svoboda et al., 1993) and other techniques (Coffman and Wu, 2012) and were able to count ∼10 steps.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: With more recent step-finding algorithms (Kerssemakers et al., 2006;Kalafut and Visscher, 2008;Carter et al., 2008), the number of detectable steps increases to ∼15-30 (Das et al., 2007;Engel et al., 2009;Coffman and Wu, 2012).
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: The latest approaches-relying on the Schwarz information criterion (SIC; also sometimes called the Bayesian information criterion; Schwarz, 1978;Chen et al., 2014) and the Student's two-sample t test (Chen et al., 2014)-encounter problems for >20 steps and SNR < 2.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Although SIC and Student's t-test algorithms improve how many steps may be detected, visual inspection, supplemented by filtering methods, is still often used (Engel et al., 2009).
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: One shortcoming of these previous methods is that they do not directly account for on-off blinking or stochastically varying noise.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Here we present a Bayesian approach to counting that directly addresses the foregoing challenges.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Conceptually, our method uses a likelihood function that is adapted to treat the physics of the noise properties expected in photobleaching and introduces a prior that corrects for systematic biases that would otherwise arise from simple likelihood maximization.

body_text.text: However, we cannot simply maximize our likelihood, since, as is well known, likelihood maximization would overfit the data by favoring too many steps in the photobleaching time trace (Kalafut and Visscher, 2008).
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Typically, to prevent overfitting, model selection criteria-including the SIC (Schwarz, 1978;Cavanaugh and Neath, 1999), the Akaike information criterion (AIC; Akaike, 1974), and others (Kadane and Lazar, 2004; reviewed most recently in Tavakoli et al., 2016)-compare different models on the basis of

body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Our Bayesian approach uses model averaging-a method that also inspired the SIC-to penalize complex models.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: The idea behind model averaging is simple: the likelihood function depends on a number of parameters (models), and, by averaging over these models, we account for models that are both good and bad fits to the data.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Fundamentally, this process penalizes complexity by weighing into consideration models that are poor fits to the data (Schwarz, 1978;Tavakoli et al., 2016).

body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Traces are typically obtained when fluorophore-tagged molecules of interest are illuminated at some time, say t = 0, and then monitored until all fluorophores have photobleached.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Photobleaching time traces present a model selection problem (Ludden et al., 1994;Cavanaugh and Neath, 1999;Stoica and Selen, 2004;Kalafut and Visscher, 2008;Pressé et al., 2013) for which a different number of steps and their locations within the trace, that is, the "model," must be found.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Concretely, we use a Bayesian method to determine both the number of photobleaching steps, K, and their location in time, s = {s 1 , • • • , s K }.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: We call each possible {s, K} pair a model.
body_text.section: METHODOLOGY A brief sketch of our approach

body_text.text: Our method is implemented in a two-step algorithm intended to greatly reduce the computational requirements by eliminating from consideration a large number of unlikely models and thus limit the number of models whose relative merit (maximum marginal posterior) we must compare.

The following conditions hold when we have blinking and overlapping events in a photobleaching time trace:
body_text.section: A criterion that incorporates blinking and overlapping events.

In practice, computing and comparing the marginal posterior, or equivalently Eq.

body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: To reduce the computational cost, nested (also called greedy) approaches are used (Chen et al., 2014), in which, for instance, a single trial step is placed at a point in time and a selection criterion, such as the SIC or AIC, is calculated.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: If a single step provides a value for the criterion that is lower than the criterion with no step, then this step is retained, and the process is repeated (holding the first step fixed) to find the possible location of a second step.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: More steps are subsequently found in this way until any single additional step only increases the value of the criterion.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: Although this approximate treatment is relatively efficient, it still requires roughly O(NK) calculations, where N is the total number of data points and K, as before, is the total number of steps.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: Instead of this classic nested approach, to improve computational efficiency and accuracy (defined later), we employ the following three-step method.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: Step 1: We find the mean and SD of the single fluorophore and background from the data, if not already known experimentally.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: In other words, assuming μ f , σ f , μ b , and σ b are a priori unknown, we determine these quantities by employing a version of a greedy algorithm (Kalafut and Visscher, 2008) to locate the last steps in the trace-that is, where the noise level is lowest -that provide us with an estimate for μ f , σ f , μ b , and σ b .
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: Step 2: Eliminate unlikely models.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: We propose a principled method to eliminate a vast number of improbable models (e.g., such as the extreme example of having all fluorophores simultaneously photobleach), leaving our criterion, Eq.

body_text.text: For a total number of G windows of size n c with α − β events per window, we must compute the criterion value a number of times that is roughly of the order Gn c (α − β ).
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: If we set N = 100,000, I = 50, G = 1000, n c = 100, and α − β = 5, we get that a nested algorithm requires NI = 5 × 10 6 calculations, whereas our method requires Gn c (α − β ) = 5 × 10 5 calculations.

body_text.text: In other words, our approach reduces computational requirements by an order of magnitude.

body_text.text: In reality, because photobleaching is an exponential process, the vast majority of windows especially toward the end of the trace will have few or no events.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: For typical photobleaching time traces with up to 10 3 data points, our algorithm works in seconds.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: For data sets that have between 1000 and 10,000 data points our algorithm runs in seconds to a few minutes.
body_text.section: Algorithm description

body_text.text: For example, in a test of a very large data set that was specifically designed to be hard to fit, performed on an ordinary MacBook Pro 2.5 GHz laptop, the Tdetector2 algorithm, which is based on Student's twosample t test as implemented in MATLAB by Chen et al. (2014), required ∼7 d to run the 5 × 10 4 -data point data set with 50 steps; our method needed 17 h.

body_text.text: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations
There are two major constraints to our method's applicability:
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: 1. We assume that each individual fluorophore is independent and has identical properties μ f and σ f that do not change in time.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: This
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: To estimate the fluorophore number in each window, we note that any data point along a photobleaching time trace must ultimately be sampled from a normal probability distribution, p i , of mean iμ f + μ b and variance iσ f
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: For each sequence of n c data points, we can quantify the likelihood that all n c data points were sampled from p i .
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: This is the likelihood that all points in that window were sampled during a time when i fluorophores were active, given the data in the window.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: The most likely number of fluorophores active in each window is the specific value of i for which this likelihood is maximum.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: We assume that in the first window (which is the last timewise, since we are moving through the data in reverse), all data points are sampled from p 0 .
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: We then move to the next window, where we compare the values of the likelihoods for a certain range of i values based on the number of fluorophores that were active in the previous window we examined.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: For example, if in the previous window the most likely number of active fluorophores was k (so that the data were drawn from p k ), we search the distributions {p k−i max , p k+1−i max ,…, p k−1+i max , p k+i max }, where i max is set to some arbitrary but reasonable value depending on k.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: If k − i max < 0, we stop searching at p 0 since there can never be a negative number of active fluorophores.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: Any time two neighboring windows are found to have different numbers of most likely active fluorophores, say p α and p β , where we take α > β, then α − β events have probably occurred.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: Moving in reverse through the trace in this manner, we estimate the most likely number of events that occurred in any window ( Figure 5).
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: Note that dividing up the data set into small windows increases both accuracy and computational time.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: However, very small FIGURE 5: How Step 2 of our algorithm works: The synthetic data (blue) are divided into G = 6 windows (black squares).
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: For each window, we calculate i likelihoods.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: Each of these is the likelihood that all data points within the window were taken when i fluorophores were active.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: Once we have all i likelihoods, we compare them and assign the window the number of fluorophores for which the likelihood is maximized.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: In this example, Step 2 has determined that the data points in windows 0 and 1 most likely belong to the p 0 distribution (no fluorophores active, only background), the data points in windows 2 and 3 most likely belong to the p 1 distribution (one fluorophore active), and the data points in windows 4 and 5 most likely belong to the p 2 and p 4 distributions, respectively, which means that two fluorophores are active in window 4 and four in 5.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: When Step 3 of our algorithm treats this trace, it will use the results from Step 2 to focus on reasonable preselected models.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: For example, it will focus primarily on models that have two to four active fluorophores in windows 4 and 5.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: yields correct results.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: Still, if both aSNR and number of data points between steps decrease, confidence in our algorithm's results should decrease as well.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: For most systems, the number of data points acquired between possible steps is a matter of experimental design.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: Whereas fluorophore photobleaching is a random process and events with separation <50 data points are bound to occur, by tuning, for instance, laser intensity, an experiment can be designed to ensure that the majority of events have a separation of >50 data points on average.
body_text.section: Applicability of our approach: theoretical and computational limitations

body_text.text: RESULTS
Benchmarking on synthetic data
To test our algorithm's performance, we first test our method on synthetic data sets in which the actual step locations are known.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: We start by discussing qualitative comparisons and subsequently define metrics that will allow us to make quantitative comparisons.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: All data sets were created using the Gillespie algorithm (Gillespie, 1977) by starting with N fluorophores each with prespecified kinetics (photobleaching and blinking-on/ off rates).
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: We then created a trace, which we call the noiseless or denoised time trace, by plotting the total number of active fluorophores multiplied by μ f and then added noise.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: Once we generated these data, we ask whether we can determine the number of steps, K, and their locations, s.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: We tested various choices of hyperparameters and user-input parameters (n, i max , w, etc., as defined in our algorithm) for the best results as quantified by the metrics defined later.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: To measure our algorithm's performance and compare it to alternate tools, we tested various methods (including our own) on our synthetic data sets.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: The performance metrics we use are based on the number and location of events-which, we recall, are single-fluorophore intensity level changes-because a step may be made up of more than one single event when considering overlapping events.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: Our metrics are defined as follows:
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: 1. Precision (PR): the ratio of the number of true events found (exact or displaced; see later discussion) to the total number of events found.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: 2. Sensitivity (SE): the ratio of the number of true events found (exact or displaced) to the total number of true events.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: 3. Offset (OF): the average distance (in terms of data points) between the location of a true event and the location of the found event.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: This is a metric that can capture the cases in which an event is identified close to, but not quite on, its true location, in which case we call it a displaced true event.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: We identify an event as a displaced true event only if the event found is within a distance d (in terms of data points) from the true event.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: We set d to be the minimum of 50 data points or 0.1%N, where N is the total number of data points in an entire trace.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: If more than one event is found within d of the true event, we take the closest one as the displaced event.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: If both are equally distant assumes that the fluorophore maturation process is complete for all fluorophores; that, following a blinking event, the fluorophore fluoresces just as it did earlier; that all fluorophores are imaged on nearby z-planes; and that the orientation of fluorophores that are not freely rotating does not affect their fluorescence properties (Backlund et al., 2014).
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: For example, for a large complex, one can imagine that the observed fluorescence intensity of a particular fluorophore within that complex might depend on the fluorophore's orientation and location within the complex, so that not all photobleaching events give rise to an equal μ f (Backlund et al., 2014), or, if a fluorophore is not freely rotating, the number of detected photons emitted by the fluorophore might depend on the angle between their orientation and the detector, which could change over time.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: We might deal with this challenge by ascribing a prior over the μ f 's informed by the physics of the problem and integrating over a range of acceptable μ f 's in our posterior.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: 2. Our method is only as good as the data.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: With insufficient data, step locations can no longer be reliably determined.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: Thus we assume that the data resolution is high enough that even at the start of the trace, the number of data points between fluorescence level changes is at least 50.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: This number of data points between steps is sufficient for adjusted SNR (aSNR), where aSNR = 2(μ ϕ +1 − μ ϕ )/(σ ϕ +1 + σ ϕ ), and ϕ is an interval (for the full definition of aSNR, see Results) down to 0.25.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: If the aSNR is larger, we need fewer data points between steps to be accurate.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: On the contrary, if the aSNR is smaller, we need larger numbers of data points between steps for our algorithm to accurately locate them.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: Having few data points between events runs the risk of introducing small-number statistics errors in our method, primarily in the form of having close-by real steps confused for double steps.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: However, it is often the case that, even when the aSNR is low (<0.25) and the data points between steps <50, our algorithm FIGURE 6: The three steps of our algorithm can be broken down into a step-by-step chart.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: In this schematic, n c is the window size, i max is the maximum number of fluorophores simultaneously considered in a window, w is the maximum number of single-level fluorescence change events the code will consider (essentially setting m = w, but only within one window), and γ 0 is a hyperparameter cutoff.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: These four quantities are the user-defined parameters that our approach requires.
body_text.section: Benchmarking on synthetic data

body_text.text: Note that since the trace has been reversed, the "first" window and the "first" two steps of the algorithm discussed in Kalafut and Visscher (2008) are timewise the last window and the latest two steps in the trace.

body_text.text: Analysis of the experimental data sets
We present the analysis on five data sets:
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: 1. Data set I (published data): We used green fluorescent protein (GFP)-tagged mitotic centromere-associated kinase (MCAK) protein provided by the Walczak group (Ems-McClung et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: MCAK proteins-members of the kinesin-13 protein family-are involved in spindle assembly during mitosis, chromosome segregation, and error correction (Walczak et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: MCAK is also unique among kinesins because it can bind to microtubule ends directly from solution and rapidly diffuse along the microtubule; once attached to the microtubule's end, it causes a conformational change that results in microtubule depolymerization and its own detachment.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: It is known (Walczak et al., 2013) that when Aurora B kinase phosphorylates MCAK, the latter's depolymerization activity is inhibited.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: To discover the mechanism of inhibition, MCAK proteins were tagged with GFP, and photobleaching event counting was used to see how quickly they detached from a microtubule.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: 2. Data set II (published data): We used Alexa Fluor 55-tagged RAD51 proteins provided by the Peterman and Wuite groups (van Mameren et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: RAD51 is a recombinase protein.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: It catalyzes strand exchange between homologous DNA segments (Sung et al., 2003), a key meiotic event that assures genetic diversity (van Mameren et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: RAD51 forms a helical filament around single-stranded DNA; this filament then locates the homologous double-stranded DNA, invades it, and catalyzes the strand exchange needed to create a joint molecule, following which the RAD51 filament disassembles to enable other proteins to conclude the process.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: The disassembly from the filament requires hydrolysis of ATP bound at the interface between adjacent RAD51 monomers.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: To determine the precise disassembly mechanism, RAD51 monomers were labeled with Alexa Fluor 555 and photobleaching time traces taken to determine the number of monomers per filament and their detachment rate from the filament.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: 3. Data sets III-V (new data): Here we used our method on data sets acquired during experiments intended to investigate how drug delivery systems (DDS) work at the cellular level.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: A challenge in the optimization of DDS is the ability to accurately quantify from the true event, we conservatively accept neither as a displaced event and consider the true event as missed.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: If a step found is not of size (number of single-level events) equal to the corresponding true step, we only consider correct the number of events up to overlap size.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: For example, if there is a triple step in the trace but we only find a double step, we consider two events found and one event missed.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: Similarly, if there is, say, a reactivation event and we find a double step, we consider three events missed.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: 4. Adjusted signal-to-noise ratio (aSNR): defined as 2(μ ϕ + 1 − μ ϕ )/ (σ ϕ + 1 + σ ϕ ), where μ ϕ and σ ϕ are the mean and SD of the ϕ th interval (recall that an interval is the stretch of data points between two identified steps).
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: This is a step-specific measure of the noise that, contrary to the simpler μ f /σ f metric, captures the increasing difficulty of identifying a step when there are many active fluorophores (i.e., at the start of a trace).
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: aSNR is given as a range from its value at the trace end to its value at the trace start.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: Under these metrics, optimal performance implies unity precision and sensitivity (all true events found and no false events found) and zero offset (all events found at their precise locations), whereas the range of aSNR is a measure of how hard a data set is to fit.
body_text.section: Analysis of the experimental data sets

body_text.text: These metrics can be used to compare algorithm performance on synthetic data sets but cannot be used on real experimental data, where the true steps are unknown.

body_text.text: Data set analysis results
Having benchmarked our method on synthetic data, we now summarize our method's analysis of all experimental data sets in Figures  8-12.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: For data set I (Figure 8), our algorithm identifies four fluorescence levels (including the background-only level).
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: For data set II (Figure 9), our method finds two steps and determines that the very first data points in the trace arise from noise and not a third fluorophore.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: Considering that both traces have high SNR (∼2 and ∼4, respectively), we can verify our algorithm's findings by eye.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: For data sets III in Figure 10 and IV in Figure 11, our method's results respectively conflict and agree with the results of the original analysis method, which was a combination of noise filtering and estimation of fluorescence levels identifiable by eye (a fuller description of the original analysis method can be found in later subsections on Trace extraction and Data analysis).
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: Whereas this original analysis method concluded that there are three steps in Figure 10, our method finds seven steps because it identified a blinking event.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: On the contrary, for Figure 11, our and the original analysis method agree on four steps.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: We note that errors due to small-number statistics when processing data set IV are more likely than when processing data set III.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: We therefore have more confidence in our analysis of data set III, despite the fact that our method's results disagree with the original data analysis method.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: For data set V in Figure 12, our method finds >30 steps, including multiple reactivation and overlapping events.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: The latter are particularly prevalent early in the trace, which is expected if there are many fluorophores active to begin with and the data acquisition rate is relatively low.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: This is because photobleaching events are more frequent early in a trace, and if more than one event occurs between successive measurements, they will register as an overlapping event.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: It is worth noting that the original filtering-and-eye analysis method found this data set intractable and could not resolve any steps.
body_text.section: Data set analysis results

body_text.text: Comparison to other methods
Our method treats blinking, stochastic noise variations, and overlapping events that may arise from interacting fluorophores or slower time acquisition.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Our method can be generalized to treat a range of μ f 's and σ f 's, although in this work, we assume these are fixed to some determinable value.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: In this section, we compare our approach to existing methods.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: The first approach is based on hidden Markov models (HMMs; Messina et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: These methods are generally very reliable and have been used to great effect in other problems; however, for photobleaching event counting, HMMs are hampered because their computational cost quickly becomes prohibitive unless one limits the number of fluorescence intensity states that can be considered.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: For example, in Messina et al. (2006), working on multichromophore photobleaching, to make the model computationally tractable, it was necessary to postulate that only single-level jumps occur, thus eliminating the possibility to treat overlapping events; even so, the method is limited to counting 30-40 fluorophores.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Another common approach relies on using some test or criterion to determine the number and location of photobleaching when, where, and how much drug release occurs inside the targeted cell.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Recently ensemble fluorescence microscopy-based techniques have begun to be used to simultaneously answer these questions in a semiquantitative manner.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Although these experiments sufficiently guide scientists to determine when large release events occur from endosomal compartments, they are insufficient to analyze slow-release events, low DDS concentrations, and events that occur outside of the endocytotic transport pathway (e.g., directly into the cytoplasm).
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: By contrast, photobleaching event counting holds the promise to quantify release of DDS cargo more accurately (Pitchiaya et al., 2012(Pitchiaya et al., , 2013(Pitchiaya et al., , 2014Shankar et al., 2016).
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: FIGURE 8: Our analysis of a trace obtained on GFP-tagged MCAK protein.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: These data are expected to show a large reactivation event and two or three steps, as the GFP-tagged proteins that have attached to a microtubule are first activated and then detach from the microtubule.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Our method identifies the initial triple activation (a large initial activation event is expected when the fluorophores are first illuminated) and then finds two more steps (one double and one single).
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Given the small number of fluorophores and the low noise level, our findings are consistent with steps identifiable by eye.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: FIGURE 9: Our analysis of a trace obtained on Alexa Fluor 555-tagged RAD51 proteins.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: In keeping with our expectation for how noise should change as more fluorophores are active, we identify two steps and determine that the small rise at the very start of the trace arises from noise, contrary to the analysis in van Mameren et al. (2009).
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: At low noise, our findings are again consistent with steps identifiable by eye.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: method performs better than the fixed-noise model because it avoids the excessive overfitting exhibited by the fixed-noise model at the high-noise, high-fluorophore start of the trace.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: We also outperform the Tdetector2 algorithm because
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: 1) it does not explicitly consider blinking and overlapping events, and
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: 2) it overestimates the number of active fluorophores, a problem that we also encountered but resolved through our prior, which is discussed in more detail in the Appendix.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: We also note that the data set we used to test our algorithm against the Tdetector2 algorithm purposefully violates our desideratum of minimally having 50 data points between successive steps.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Nevertheless, our algorithm still outperforms the alternatives; see legends to Figures 13 and 14 for details.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: As a final note, we stress that our algorithm does not involve smoothing or filtering, which removes information on fast-time scale kinetics.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Finally, there are many miscellaneous methods, from simple ones such as measuring the fluorescence "step" size from the late trace where steps can be detected by eye and using it to determine the number of fluorophores initially active, to more elaborate ones, such as using a Γ-distribution and dividing starting intensity by the result (Coffman and Wu, 2012), to using a binomial distribution with many traces to determine the most probable maximum fluorophore number (Das et al., 2007), to using the propagation of information with feedback algorithm (McGuire et al., 2012).
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Such methods have faced problems when dealing with a large number (20-30) of fluorophores and low SNR.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: A recent method, spot number intensity correlation (SONIC; Liesche et al., 2015), is an innovative method that determines the total number of fluorophore-tagged subunits based on a statistical analysis of measurements of the time to total bleaching of all fluorophores in a complex.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: Because complexes with more fluorophoretagged subunits take longer to decay to background fluorescence, the statistical analysis can yield an estimate for the total fluorophore number without determining exact step locations.
body_text.section: Comparison to other methods

body_text.text: SONIC seems to be very accurate when determining the number of fluorophores, but it has a major drawback, in that it cannot locate photobleaching steps in time and therefore cannot address problems for which kinetic measurements are needed, such as when MCAK proteins move in and out of the spindle assembly during mitosis.

body_text.text: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Here we describe the experiments that produced the unpublished data sets that we tested with our method.
body_text.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS

body_text.text: Preparation of fluorescent microRNA duplexes

MicroRNA-7 (miR-7) guide and passenger oligonucleotides were synthesized with a 5′ phosphate and, in the case of the labeled guide strand, a 3′ NHS-ester-linked Alexa Fluor 647 (Integrated DNA Technologies, Coralville, IA).
body_text.section: Preparation of fluorescent microRNA duplexes

body_text.text: Guide and passenger strands were HPLC purified by Integrated DNA Technologies, and their size and purity were verified by denaturing, 8 M urea, 20% PAGE.
body_text.section: Preparation of fluorescent microRNA duplexes

body_text.text: For the guide strand, 90% of the RNA was found to be singly labeled, as determined by quantifying the molar ratio of fluorophore to RNA through ultraviolet-visible absorbance measurements.
body_text.section: Preparation of fluorescent microRNA duplexes

body_text.text: Guide and passenger strands were heat annealed at a 1:1.5 ratio in 1× phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; 70011; Life Technologies, Delhi, India) to a final concentration of 10 μM.
body_text.section: Preparation of fluorescent microRNA duplexes

body_text.text: The extent of duplex formation was assessed using an electrophoretic mobility shift assay on a nondenaturing 20% polyacrylamide gel.
body_text.section: Preparation of fluorescent microRNA duplexes

body_text.text: The miR-7 passenger and guide strand sequences were as follows: miR-7 guide: 5′-p-UGGAAGACUAGUGAUUUUGUUGU-3′, miR-7 passenger: 5′-p-CAACAAAUCACAGUCUGCCAUA-3′.
body_text.section: Preparation of fluorescent microRNA duplexes

body_text.text: Cell culture and transfection
HeLa cells (CCL-2; American Type Culture Collection, Manassas, VA) were grown in an incubator and held at 37°C in an atmosphere with 5% CO 2 and 95% relative humidity.
body_text.section: Cell culture and transfection

body_text.text: Cells were maintained in DMEM (11995; GIBCO, Langley, OK), supplemented with 10% (vol/vol) fetal bovine serum and 100 U/ml penicillinstreptomycin (15140122; ThermoFisher Scientific, Waltham, MA).
body_text.section: Cell culture and transfection

body_text.text: On reaching ∼80% confluency, cells were split and seeded onto DeltaT (Bioptechs, Butler, PA) dishes to a density of 1 × 10 5 cells/ dish.
body_text.section: Cell culture and transfection

body_text.text: After 24 h, each dish of cells had half of its medium removed and was supplemented with 500 μl of transfection mixture (Lipofectamine 2000 [11668019;Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA] and 40 pmol of miR-7 duplex in OptiMEM [31985070; Invitrogen]).
body_text.section: Cell culture and transfection

body_text.text: To prevent overloading the cell with excessive fluorescently labeled miR-7, only 1% of the total duplexed guide strand contained Alexa Fluor 647.
body_text.section: Cell culture and transfection

body_text.text: After a 4-h incubation period, the transfection mixture was replaced with fresh medium.
body_text.section: Cell culture and transfection

body_text.text: At 6 h after transfection, the cells were washed thrice with 1× PBS, followed by a 20-min incubation with a 4% (wt/vol) paraformaldehyde and 1× PBS mixture for fixation.
body_text.section: Cell culture and transfection

body_text.text: The cells were then washed thrice with 1× PBS, immersed in oxygen scavenger system (OSS; 5 mM protocatechuic acid, protocatechuate-3,4-dioxygenase, and 2 mM Trolox [6-hydroxy-2,5,7,8-tetramethylchroman-2-carboxylic acid]), covered, and sealed using Valap sealant.
body_text.section: Cell culture and transfection

body_text.text: Single-molecule imaging

Microscopy imaging was conducted as previously described (Pitchiaya et al., 2012(Pitchiaya et al., , 2014(Pitchiaya et al., , 2013Shankar et al., 2016), using a home-built IX-81 Olympus microscope with a 60×, 1.49 numerical aperture oil immersion objective (Olympus, Lombard, IL), 2× magnification wheel, P-545.3C7 capacitive piezoelectric xyz-stage
body_text.section: Single-molecule imaging

body_text.text: DISCUSSION
Superresolution single-molecule microscopy methods are poised to provide information on protein complex stoichiometry with high spatial resolution (Lee et al., 2012;Rollins et al., 2015).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Spatial resolution in itself is important because it may distinguish, for instance, between true colocalization of protein species and random spatial patterning below the diffraction limit (Xia et al., 2013).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Despite its advantages, counting from superresolution data may become computationally expensive (Rollins et al., 2015) except when realized via very sparse activations-but in that case, the experiments are difficult-and may be complicated by photophysical artifacts such as incomplete maturation of the fluorophore (Durisic et al., 2014).
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Although photobleaching event counting does not provide subdiffraction-limited information, it is computationally inexpensive and, for this reason, more complicated effects (such as blinking) can more feasibly be incorporated into the analysis of larger data sets.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Here we argue that the key to successfully analyzing large photobleach data sets is to use the expected physics of the fluorophores to inform the step-finding process.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: This strategy reduces the number of errors arising from stochastically varying noise, blinking, and event overlap that arise in the methods to which we have compared ours.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: For simple cases with few (<20) fluorophores or high aSNR (>1), our method does better than or just as well as coarser algorithms that ignore variance changes or blinking and overlap.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: However, our method does remarkably better on more challenging synthetic data sets and, presumably, would perform equally well in experimental FIGURE 13: Our method greatly improves on the results of methods that treat noise as fixed.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Trace extraction

Original trace analysis (done and then compared with the method described here) was performed using a custom-written Lab-View (National Instruments, Austin, TX) software code similar to previously described procedures (Pitchiaya et al., 2012(Pitchiaya et al., , 2013.
body_text.section: Trace extraction

body_text.text: In short, the LabView code uses noise-filtering and photon-counting histogram algorithms to identify particles of interest and removes nonuniform background from all selected traces.
body_text.section: Trace extraction

body_text.text: The data were filtered further by a nonlinear Chung-Kennedy noise filter to preserve fast and sudden signal transitions while averaging out random noise.
body_text.section: Trace extraction

body_text.text: The filtered data were then assessed by eye, with each sudden decrease in signal classified as a photobleaching event.
body_text.section: Trace extraction

body_text.text: For each trace, the number of photobleaching events corresponds to the total fluorescent miR-7 molecules within a focus since >90% of dye molecules are found to be fluorescent (Pitchiaya et al., 2012(Pitchiaya et al., , 2013.
body_text.section: Trace extraction

body_text.text: Data analysis: fixed-cell photobleaching analysis of transfected fluorescent miR-7 duplex

To test the photobleaching event counting method described here in a biological context, we conducted a single-molecule photobleaching analysis to test the oligomerization state of transfected fluorescent miR-7 duplex in fixed HeLa cells.
body_text.section: Data analysis: fixed-cell photobleaching analysis of transfected fluorescent miR-7 duplex

body_text.text: Six hours after transfection, our cells were fixed in a 4% paraformaldehyde solution, immersed in OSS, and illuminated using HILO fluorescence microscopy.
body_text.section: Data analysis: fixed-cell photobleaching analysis of transfected fluorescent miR-7 duplex

body_text.text: Videos of single cells were acquired until all cellular fluorescent particles were photobleached into a permanent dark state.
body_text.section: Data analysis: fixed-cell photobleaching analysis of transfected fluorescent miR-7 duplex

body_text.text: The original analysis was performed as described; via our custom LabView software, fluorescent particles were identified and background subtracted.
body_text.section: Data analysis: fixed-cell photobleaching analysis of transfected fluorescent miR-7 duplex

body_text.text: Then noise was filtered to help identify by eye intensity transitions relevant to the photobleaching process.
